treasury_and_investment.overview: Hyndburn manages its treasury operations to fund capital investment and manage cash flow. The Council borrows to fund capital projects including the Levelling Up Fund regeneration of Accrington Town Centre and investment in the Leisure Estate.

key_context.borrowing: Capital Programme totals £44.87M (2024/25-2028/29). Major borrowing relates to Levelling Up Fund projects (£24M) and Huncoat Garden Village (£30M Homes England grant).
key_context.investments: Investment income forecast at £703K for 2025/26, declining as interest rates fall. The 2024/25 surplus has been partly driven by higher-than-expected investment returns.
key_context.mrp: Minimum Revenue Provision of £1.085M plus £481K interest payable. MRP and interest costs form the majority of non-service expenditure at £863K net.
key_context.reserves: Total usable reserves forecast to fall from £26.1M (April 2024) to £8.8M (March 2026) as Levelling Up Fund capital programme progresses. General Fund Balance maintained at £2.476M.

revenue_vs_capital.explanation: Revenue budget covers day-to-day running costs (staff, services, utilities) funded by council tax, business rates and grants. Capital budget covers long-term investment in assets (buildings, infrastructure) funded by borrowing, capital grants and reserves. They are completely separate budgets.

key_trends: Revenue budget grew 6.1% from £16.3M to £17.3M in one year
Environmental Services is the largest department at £4.44M (28% of service spend)
Business Rates provide 49% of funding (£8.447M) — highest dependency of any East Lancashire council
Council Tax raised £6.064M (35% of funding) — Band D increased by £8.03 to £276.46
Total usable reserves declining sharply: £26.1M → £17.5M → £8.8M as capital programme progresses
No surplus from reserves needed in 17 years — strong financial management record
Corporate Savings Target of £163,900 (0.94%) reintroduced to balance budget
Leisure services seeing £700K additional costs due to utility, wage and NI pressures
